It's the age old disposable vs. repairable. Both have their pros and cons. Would you prefer to still be driving 1970 family sedan as your primary commuter?  Planned obsolescence and disposable help foster advancement.  For a pretty good example consider automotive safety systems and devices.  There are probably things in regard to that most people aren't even are aware of.  Like crunch zone.  Yes they make the vehicle less durable.  But they save a lot of lives and reduce a lot of injury severity.  Yes we are talking about a computer here but some of the same principles apply.  And like techbio mentioned.  The big difference is with the modules and motherboard upgrade.  Most notebooks have had up-gradable memory, storage (HDD/SSD) and WiFI for a long time.  Largely due to industry standardization. That's nothing new.  To me it would be appealing for high end notebooks to protect the larger outlay $$$ from becoming a paper weight due to some failure. High end is not just measured in terms of processing performance.  But also by the feature set.  Like Large touch screen with active stylus.
One module bay is pretty much dedicated for power/charging.  Leaving only 3 for "real" usage.  Should either have 6 bays or a dedicated charging port aside from the 4 bays.  Power/charging is something every computer needs.  Give it a dedicated port.  Could even be a swap-able module for various physical power connection form-factors.  For instance USB-C, 3.5mm barrel, etc.
Small screen, no touch, no active stylus, no go. For premium price it must have 15.6" screen, touch and active stylus.  Otherwise it's a non starter at those prices.
The only significant appeal of this compared to existing laptops is the modular swappable units. HP, Dell, Lenovo etc can all be opened easily enough and memory, battery, wireless cards and storage swapped out. But being able to add hdmi, display port etc, change number of usb-c ports and so on, is very innovative. However you are still locked into the manufacturer for modules. What I'd like to see is swappable modules that you can mount your own mini pci-e cards in. So you can buy pci-e cards from any source and install them in the module and plug directly into the module port on the laptop. That would be true platform independent upgradeability and customisability.  That said I'm not dissing in this laptop, it's very appealing and something I will consider when I reach the end of the upgrade path on my current HP 11th Gen laptop.
I've watched this video a couple times just because it was interresting, and now, I think Linus has convinced me I want this even though I am not going to buy it anytime soon because I just bought the GDP pocket 3. It was between a GDP laptop, and the Dell XPS for a while there and now I'm adding the framework to my list of favorite laptops, kind of like a cool car a might someday own.
Sadly, this is too expensive for my paycheck.

I adore the concept of modular laptops & phones, however I kinda cringe when I see them on the market nowadays. They tend to be made by start ups that have a huge marketing campaign, but nothing in the way of sustainable investors. Also, bc it's an enthusiast device, there's no agreed upon standardization - everything is proprietary. This means their method of modularity is limited to the modules the start up sells, & a lot of the time replacement modules aren't easy to come across. Consider Fairphone (the only modular device company I'm aware of that's stuck around) - they're currently on gen 4, & while I can't speak for the 4th gen, I can confirm gens 1 & 2 we're a nightmare bc when they jumped to 2 none of the modules for 1 were compatible & the company was having difficulty (or more accurately, they stopped caring ) in getting the gen 1 parts produced. So, if your charger port for you phone was out, you should just buy a new phone.

Its not because they "dont trust" their users. almost EVERY company that makes functional products like electronics, appliances, automobiles progressively implements ways to make repairs more and more difficult many times to the point of not letting anyone do it like apple famously did, but also designing them in ways that make them fail, and adding things that make the parts non modular or inaccessible, etc. Some time before the 21st century refrigerators were made with their compressors and coolant in an easily accesible corner that was simply hidden by a metal panel you just unscrewed for the sake of aesthetics. Well at some point the completely close that compartment; literally surround the ONLY actively functional parts in a steel box that you would risk busting the compressor and dying from the shockwave or puncturing the freon reservoir, or electrocute yourself. So now instead of spending $50 to have a technician come and repair it in about 10mins guaranteed no matter what could possibly be wrong with it  cause theres only so much that could, now you HAVE to pay to have your old one lugged away and disposed properly and spend several hundred dollars on the cheapest of non used fridges. Thats why they do it linus. Because how are they supposed to make their target %6 growth every year until the end of time if youre just being selfish and saving money keeping a perfectly functional and repairable one. Thats why they do it. Thats why theres only two types of technician now. COMPUTER ELECTRONICS, and auto-repair/maintenance. All the money that was driving that entire career path that was ALOT easier for poor to middle class to get an infinitely cheaper education than university and to get a government certification in a career that broke its back along with so many holding up the middle class, and the opportunity for even mediocre success provided to us against the weight of the INFINITE GREED of the ultra wealthy that KNOW their oligarchic practices making our mixed ideology economy as close to la ze faire ad the can not only will not work but CANT work if youre already raping the land and poisoning the people that call it home to extract even more finite resources than we as a species already have. I'm sorry, but where does the $300 of savings from self-assembly instead of pre-assembled figure come from? The laptop in DIY configuration STARTS at $749, and that is before you even add the wi-fi card, storage, ram, power adapter and ports to the configuration, so the starting price is incredibly misleading, unless you want a laptop with a CPU, battery, screen and keyboard, and nothing else. After all of the lowest cost options for a fully functional laptop are added (power adapter included) the price ends up being $1,021, which is more than a pre-assembled one at $1000 for the cheapest model (can be cheaper if you don't need certain ports). What gives? What is the point of the DIY option if it ends up being more expensive to assemble a laptop yourself?

14:30 - the "next" in driver installers is about signal of intent, and the ability to back out instead of accidentally installing the wrong driver that temporarily removes functionality (instead of the tedious process of booting into safemode, removing the driver, and restarting the device to install the new one again). that's a necessary evil, given how many companies throw every single driver for multiple products on one page and the ambiguity of those drivers being compatible.  framework has a massive advantage by only having one SKU of motherboard/laptop, so only having one current set of drivers for their current vendors of i/o prevents confusion, but once they start sourcing parts from other companies or producing more SKUs, an unattended driver installer might become a bane more than a boon.

Instead of having to buy a new unit after a few years when the components become outdated or break & spend tonnes of money, you can just upgrade the components, which also reduces e-waste! Of course the big tech companies hate this because their profit margins would shrink if people weren‚Äôt basically forced to continually buy new products, but the freedom of choice of us end users & greater sustainability is far more important

I bought one of these laptops, I got the model with the i5-1135g7 becuase in my research it's performance wasn't significantly different from the I7. I bought mine with the least hardware i could except for the charger and ports (TypeC, HDMI, usb x2). I took components (32gb ddr4, 2Tb 980 pro, intel AC9260) from my Lenovo P1 Gen 1 (I7-8850H & Quadro P2000) Which i had expected this to be a straight downgrade as the 8850H is a more powerful cpu and the dedicated GPU should be much better in gaming related tasks.   I was not prepared for the amount of difference the encoding improvements in the i5 1135g7 made to my experience. For the first time, I could stream games over my local network without any significant loss of quality. Previously when attempting to do this on my P1 even at 720p i was bottlenecked by the rate at which the cpu could decode the incoming stream from my desktop (5900x & 3080 ti). Now I can stream at my laptops native 2k resolution without any artifacting whatsoever.   I also found the improvements to integrated graphics to be good at running even newer games (tested Humankind) at medium settings. (Of course it's not as good as the P2000, which is about equivalent to a 1060 6gb, but the difference is high settings vs medium settings). Which is the highest level of performance id need on the move. Combine all that with the brighter 3:2 14in screen with great battery life (i use my laptop in my car for work a lot) this laptop has been outstanding.   I had concerns about lacking camera windows hello, but the finger print sensor is of high quality and wakes quicker without accidentally waking the device and logging into the wrong account. (Useful when you have work and personal accounts)  I am very happy with my Framework laptop and I am confident i can replace any part that could fail, I will use this laptop for many years.
I want one and i want to support them too.

I do not understand their purpose. They seem to be anti-Apple and anti-Microsoft gimmick. Many companies like MSI and Asus sell laptops which can be easily opened, repaired, and upgraded (as much as this laptop can). These companies void warranty when you open, but Framework allow you to open only. If it gets damaged during repair/upgrade or if you use parts which Framework do not provide then warranty is void. Basically you are tied to Framework if you buy their laptop, which isn't good. And in 3-4 years this laptop will be obsolete and you will require a new laptop anyways. CPU/GPU upgrades are not a thing and if you are replacing motherboard then why not replace whole laptop for a change. They have created cute tiny modules for ports and SSD but they are too small to get lost easily. We all know how many stuff we lose. And if even 2-3 people bring the same laptop to a meeting and put those tiny modules on a table then it will be a nightmare to figure out which belongs to whom. Personally I do not like their vision. As a laptop person I would prefer to have a laptop which I never need to open. I do not like opening my laptop to clean fans. I want a laptop which never gets dirty from inside and if I want to add RAM and storage then I would prefer to have option to choose which RAM and storage I want at the time of purchase. Companies lie all the time about the parts they use. If Framework should have focused on that vision where they have transparency in parts they use, it would have been really innovative and revolutionary. I would prefer that I know what parts companies are using at the time of purchase and better to have an option to choose which part I want.

Those expansion slots look wide enough for 2 usb-c ports. If so, the usb-c module probably should've had two. I don't know of many situations where a built-in hub would be an issue. If not, then the expansion slot size was chosen pretty poorly.  A lot of laptop motherboards have angled ram slots that let the ram modules overlap, using much less horizontal space for a little more vertical space. Feels like there was a missed opportunity to have a higher ram capacity and to be able to cobble together many small modules that a DIY-er might have laying around.

In regards to solid rigidity despite being really thin. It's all about profiling, bracing and anchoring. This is how we can make a platform you can walk and jump on with barely any flex, using sheet metal not much thicker than a few layers of aluminium foil. You can do a lot of it with plastics too, but sandwich and anchor some pretty thin polycarbonate or nylon with thin steel - you got yourself some serious wizardry.

Linus, the battery disconnect option in the BIOS is not only for disabling the battery when you are using wall power, it is also for easily servicing the insides of the laptop without disconnecting the battery. This feature is there in some present laptops, and since this laptop is made for modularity, it only makes sense for them to add the option in the BIOS.

So when the Fairhope review
"The justification that traditional laptop manufactures have had for making everything so integrate and so impossible to upgrade"...Yeah. That's all "smoke and mirrors", or theatre if you will. Or, you know. Lying.   It's all about planned obsolescence and end-user aftermarket control. One part breaks and you have to chuck it? You have to buy a new one. One part breaks and you try to fix their specialised, proprietary system? You either "void" the warranty, or have to take your machine in-house to fix it, where they can control the labor and the quality of repairs. It's the same with cars and car repairs. Obfuscation of design is a huge money maker.

DO NOT GET MAGNETIC CHARGING CONNECTORS FOR LAPTOPS!  I have experience with magnetic USB connectors and i can tell you right now that you will get metal bits at the ends and you will cause minor shorts. I can only imagine that they would be far more serious with much higher wattage.
Dell is going the apple route. With my job we use the dell precision lines. The 7710, 7720, 7730, 7740 all has the back panels easy to remove to access the board and take the battery out, upgrade ram, hard drives, etc... The back is split up in 2 parts. 1 is a switch that opens half of the back with no screw driver needed. This lets you access the battery and 1 of the hard drive slots. The second panel is only held by 2 screws that then drops the second half of the panel to access the rest of the board to do what you need.  The 7750 and 7760 has changed. Its a single back panel that has like 8 screws and the panel is the bottom half of the frame of the laptop not just flat panels.  So its harder to open.  This is crazy and concerning for us IT guys. I work in IT that has to open this as we get them to configure and put in the hard drives in a certain way according to our specs needed. It is a bear when you order 100 of these and have to open each and every one of them to put in the hard drives.
This will be my next laptop. Consistently, my past 5 laptops have met the end of their life when the power port wears out.

I would like to see a review and comparison to Purism's Librem 14 laptop. Purism didn't do the gimmicky (IMHO) USB-C I/O modules, but their laptops have similar privacy and user-repairability baked into their design. And given they've been around longer, I have a little bit more faith in their long term prospects.  For Framework, I'm concerned that as soon as a new USB spec is dropped, you'll need to upgrade the motherboard (and CPU/GPU) to take advantage of it, as well as buying the newer faster I/O modules. The cost of that kind of upgrade is likely to be akin to just buying a new laptop anyways, and produce a similar amount of e-waste unless Framework somehow manages to create a secondary market for obsolete used parts.

I will always remember my old Alienware M17 x R3, made in 2012 with it's dated 660M GPU and it's abhorrently loud fans. Played allot of mid range games at low settings on that thing. But what I will always remember was how easily it was to upgrade the thing. It was so big you basically had a micro-tower on your lap, with ever component given a ample amount of room, and independence so it was dirt simple to unscrew, and replace any part. I paid 200$ for that laptop used in 2019 as my first computer, and to this day would have paid easily three times that much. It never failed me and I ended up handing it down to a younger brother and it still runs to this day. Better times.

The point of right to repair is so your iphone doesn't end up in the landfill because a half cent resistor failed or the glued in battery died. Or how about a 50% chance of smashing your windshield to change or charge the battery in your car. Would you put up with that? Well this is where we are with phones. All the companies following Apple and Apple claim to be the greenest but are the biggest polluter because they resist repair of their devices at every opportunity. This is why they should be forced to support their devices and properly repair and supply parts.
I applaud Framework for trying to bring something back that once was a given or at least much more widespread. You see, we actually used to have an almost comparable amount of upgradability and repairability up to 7-8 years ago, at least with certain notebook product lines. Older models of the IBM / Lenovo T-series are a good case in point. Basically everything about these devices was upgradeable and repairable, which helped to increase the lifespan of the product significantly. To give an example, I personally still use a T430 from 2013 to this very day. Over the years, I have upgraded the CPU, RAM, main memory and display, and I have exchanged the original smaller battery for a larger one. I had to replace the entire keyboard once, and two individual keys due to wear of the mechanism under the pads. None of this was a big deal because original spare parts were widely available (Lenovo discontinued hardware support only last year or so). Owing to all of this, the device is still a decent workhorse for most computer applications. Sadly, Lenovo started soldering shit onto their mainboards like everybody else in following generations of T-series notebooks ...
This could be our future, I would be keen to see what Gen 2 looks like if enough early adopters come through.

Would also be great if they kept the main board installation as a standard and offered to the client to just buy a new motherboard instead of a whole new notebook. It would be like a Desktop PC that you don't need to buy a new monitor, keyboard, mouse, case, PSU and in many times the Memory to upgrade to the next CPU/GPU generation. They could even offer a return policy for the old main board to give a discount when you purchase the new one. This would allow them to properly recycle/repurpose those old parts.
Remember when the idea of an upgradable phone was proposed so to reduce the amount of e-waste and allow customizability for the end user to set to their preference? While that idea was quickly shut down by phone/computer manufacturers, because of bull PR propaganda, that same idea was carried over to making a portable PC by the very people who previously worked for these proprietary companies who were so hardcore on keeping their patent hardware secret. I also love that the ease of access to the internals wasn't constricted by some crazy clam shell design that you need a pick or flat tool, risk breaking off some of the plastic bits just to open and close the case. While it's just the first of it's kind, I would like to see how they would tackle a gaming PC. It would actually make me feel I'm getting my money's worth rather than feel like I'm paying for the brand name itself.
This is the critical difference between things that are built to maintained and used, as opposed to things that are built just to be sold. I appreciate it when any company specifically designs things to be user serviceable. There's more value for the end user, less e-waste as you can upgrade/fix instead of replace, and likely an inherent loyalty to the company simply because they said "We got you". I love this.

2 main gripes I have with this thing aside from the obvious uncertain future: 1: customizeable ports are nice BUT 3 (4-charging port) of anything is NOT enough for me without dongles. 2: While the hardware freedom is nice, they have to compete with the software freedom of system 76 for me.  these are very fixable though. if they had atleast one of either USB-A or a USB-C charging port built into the chassis standard that would go a long way to increasing the actual flexibility with the other ports.  -EVERYONE will need to charge the laptop and if you really want it on the other side you can still use a modular type C -type A is so widespread for things like dongles, flash drives, mice, external hard drives, and phones, it is reasonable to assume the vast majority of people will still find use for a single one somewhere on the laptop  -alternatively they could just have 6 ports though that might cut into speaker size theoretically, though they could have made the speakers themselves modular with 2 "jumbo" bays that could alternatively support larger devices with multiple ports or just the regular ports with some kind of spacer to fill the gap. I would trade out stereo sound for 2 more ports personally.   for 2 they could implement coreboot themselves, but honestly what would go a long way, is if they could partner up with system 76 and possibly other companies for alternative parts at some point in the future and instead take on the role as some sort of standardized 'framework' for other companies to compete to create parts and boards for.

Ok so lets take a look at this shall we? Base configuration vs specced up config of say a macbook air. Why a specced up air? Because this thing, in order to get a processor that performs like the M1 needs a 300 dollar processor upgrade. So 16 gigs of ram for both, core i7 for the intel machine, 256 of storage for the windows machine, and 512 for the mac. we are talking the framework comes out 40 bucks cheaper, but then if you start looking into things a bit you find that none of the expansion cards come with it. So you need to add 9 bucks on bare minimum to get a functional machine as it does not have a charging port included according to their site. You can plug into the usb c plug thats in the machine that all of these plug into themselves, but its a hassle and you risk breaking the port cause it wasn't designed for direct access. and to bring it in line with the mac you need another 256 of storage and another USB port. And now we are at the same price, replacing the 256 with 512 on their configurator brings us up another 13 bucks, and the two usb c ports add another 18 bucks. So we are at 1449 for the mac, and 1450 for the framework. Not bad. Assuming self assembly. Yup when it gets here you have to put it all together yourself, or pay 300 bucks to have that done for you. So what are you getting for the same cash if you are willing to build it yourself? Well you are getting a lessor screen for one. The mac has a 2560x1600 screen while the framework has a 2256x1504 >400 nit screen. the framework has a 55 Wh battery vs the 49 Wh battery in the Air. Both have touch ID, both have wifi 6 and such. So really the big difference is in repairability, and performance. This is closer than I honestly thought it would be, but there are some unseen tradeoffs. M1 chips are fast and power efficient partly because the ram is built onto the chip and thus not upgradeable. The mac will likely out perform this machine while being quieter and more battery efficient. This has no dedicated GPU and its unclear if the expansion cards will cause issues with eGPU's. Etc. Not to mention Apple Care is (when you aren't trying to be insane with it) one of the best loyalty repair services out there. Its really hard to call this a good deal, it does however show that until all our laptops are running SOC's, this isn't completely inviable like a lot of manufacturers would have you believe.

I got an old chromebook from my dad, he said that the repair guys had said it would take 60$ just to diagnose it. The screen was blacked out. At first I thought the screen-motherboard cable was shorted, but then it continued having issues after I replaced it. I eventually realized that the TAPE that helped keep the cable connected to the socket was a little bit weak and left the plug wobbly. I slapped a peice of duct tape on it and it hasn't ever given me problems since. Maybe it was a combination of a cord short and a plug issure, but I think it was likely just the plug.  What you should get out of this: 1: Tech repair is often overpriced. 2: Chromebooks are also really easy to fix. (Though you might want some experience before you muddle around inside one.)

I have to disagree with the sentiment. This laptop still is severely restricted in functionality: - 4 of these bays are not even close to enough. My current laptop has 2 USBa, 1 USBc, 1 HDMI, 1 miniDP, 1 ethernet, 1 SD/microSD, 1 SIM, headphone jack, mic jack and charging port. It would require a whopping 9 (!) of these bays to reach the same level of functionality. I use all of them except miniDP and i still wish i had an additional USBa port and a VGA port. - i doubt a full-size ethernet plugin will ever be made. or VGA. - the battery can't be easily detached in and out like on old laptops. i used to carry two batteries that i would swap when needed, that's how you last a weekend without charging. - no internal SATA bay. 10:20 I tell you something: The fact that you get only ONE USB SLOT PER MODULE is kind of stupid. Not every usb connected device is going to saturate the entire link, and the form factor is (at least almost) big enough to support two slots beside one another. Does it come with an ethernet port? Unlikely because that design isn't thick enough to support it. No ethernet port on my laptops is a massive no-go. So in the end, you are only limited to 4 things as per this design. Which is still a problem due to the size of it. If they really cared, you would have a DEDICATED NVME slot, that is for nothing but NVME for a much better upgradeable storage experience.  The big question is the cost of the upgrade modules, and the next big question is THEIR choice of which things are going in there. So we have to rely on their choice selection plus the cost of the modular part. We still talk proprietary form factor here. It is NOT "put in directly what you want". It is NOT "here is a tray to put your aftermarket piece of equipment in" like YOUR choice of SSD. So yeah, golfclap. They shouldn't get bonus points for doing something that has been the standard in the past.  This looks like a concept that is going the "in spite, for the people!" route. But how many of them will actually be sold remains the question. Yes, they're using the buzzword "modular" better than most others do. Yes they are nice to provide detailed information and easy accessibility with QR codes. But that is all there is to it. The real modularity that the consumers would actually appreciate is still not there, because this laptop, like anything else, remains a business decision.

I buy from them because of their great 5-year warranty, even though I know that they use a ton of used parts over and over (which I didn't mind as long as the laptop ran my games well). But I have to tell you, this is TRULY the first laptop that I hope to buy next when the time comes in 2 years. Why? Alienware still has a great warranty but the last two laptops both thermal throttle so bad and the fact that I can now replace bad parts easily (or upgrade them) means I no longer need an extended warranty. I HOPE they also start a buyback system so that I can sell my used parts back to them when I buy an upgrade. Actually Panda Project had a modular future proof PC that was easy to upgrade with I/O expansion cards, CPU/GPU expansion cards, RAM expansion cards utilizing a design for 256-bit computing support.  These days you might call it a Blade style of computer.  Modular support of drive cages meant you could expand your media drives and storage to whatever you needed.  It didn't matter what new standards came out as the whole PC was designed for easy upgrades.  And when the market went to 512-bit computing well they had that in the works as well.  It too was a commercial product that unfortunately fizzled due to extravagant prices.

Note that the DIY laptop is really $300 cheaper. It's base model is $963.00 vs. $749. But the DIY base price doesn't include an operating system, RAM or storage that is included in the prebuilt. So that's a $214 difference in price, but if you add even the 250GB NVMe drive (+$66), 8GB of RAM ($49), and Windows 10 Home ($139) that are included in the base model pre-assembled laptop, it costs $1003... which is actually more expensive. So unless you are going to BYO components for at least some of the laptop, or at least are going with Linux instead of Windows, you are better off going with a preassembled laptop.

iFixit gave this system a 10 for repairability. Only two other laptops have ever gotten that score: the HP EliteBook 800 series (versions from various years, the most recent one scored is a 2020 model) and the Dell Latitude E5270 from 2017. Those are both enterprise laptops. No consumer laptop has ever before been given a 10 by them.  And honestly... if this is a 10, nothing before it is better than a 9. Even the motherboard and the CPU cooler are dead simple to replace. (Watch the iFixit teardown video.) Those I/O modules mean that the I/O ports on the motherboard are not vulnerable to physical damage. You only need to disconnect one ribbon cable to open it up; the keyboard and trackpad cables are combined. The magnetic bezel around the display won't break when removed, unlike the plastic tabs that are so common. And you only need ONE tool to take it completely apart; every screw is a Torx T5 or a Phillips P0, and the tool has a reverseable bit.  Right now this is looking like the gold standard of how laptops should be designed. The only question that remains is how well it will stand up to years of use.

Listen, I love the idea, just how I loved the idea of the whatsitcalled modular smartphone back when, but unless somebody major joins the bandwagon, I don't see the difference between a laptop I can't upgrade and one I _could_ upgrade if replacement parts were still available, but whoops, the small startup that created them went out of business and their sleek modules aren't manufactured anymore.  Like, just as an example, the first smart watch I bought was the Sony SW50, and it had a terrible (imho) silicone wrist strap. I thought, well, no worries, there's a replacement adapter that makes it compatible with standard 24mm straps, but oooh, it's like $60 right now, I think I'll wait until my current one bites the dust before I replace it. Well, about two years later the silicone tore, I went online and... Sony had discontinued the watch, like you couldn't even find it on their products page anymore, and that neat little adapter sold for +$100 on ebay, second-hand. Fucking infuriating.  I'm not speaking about the core components like RAM or the M.2 drives, huge kudos to them for sticking with widely available components there, but the cute little plug-in cards, the keyboard and trackpad (unless Lidon and PixArt just have that form factor ready to go)... I understand that you can't make _everything_ modular and standardized, especially in a laptop, and maybe I am just too coddled by desktop PCs where I can swap basically any peripherals without even opening the case.  I _want_ to love this, both the idea and the execution, but I've been burned by the promise of "nah, don't worry if something gives up the ghost, you can fix it" and then once it's time to fix something, like, four years down the line, I'll be on ebay again scavenging for broken donor devices to rip parts from. Y'know, like we're repairing current gen laptops. I'm more than happy to change my mind in the future, don't get me wrong, it's just hard to trust somebody who promises me they have the solution when everybody before them broke that exact promise.

It is funny that I still have Samsung 900X3C from 2012... and I regularly use it when on the go because it is ultra slim/ultra portable device and it has almost all the same upgradability. Yes you can fit M-Sata driver (times before m.2), you can fit new wireless card... the ram is sadly soldered on, but it is ultra-slim laptop (and you can have 15" still ultra slim 900X4D which has upgradable ram). I have recently replaced the battery on my girlfriends laptop (she has similar 900X3E model) as there are no glue or crap on these laptops. And it is still fully usable laptop - she used it for studies and playing LOL, SC2 and many older games. I have upgraded to 512GB SSD from 128GB in mine. So there are ways of upgrading these things. The only thing which is glued is the bezel around the screen, but the screen itself is just screwed on. I have seen replacement screens and they simply come with new bezel which you can stick-on. In short, the only waste generated by replacing screen is slim piece of screen bezel (no more aluminium than in single can of coke!). One thing I wish somebody would do is the new motherboards... Imagine how awesome it would be if I could take this gorgeous ultra-slim alloy laptop from 2012 and replace crappy i7 3517U/Intel HD4000 graphics with something like Ryzen 7 5800U! Consider this - old CPU was W17TDP part, the new Ryzen is W15-25TDP part so not only it is more efficient and would make battery life better (which was not that bad to begin with ~6h when new and still get's me 2-3h today), but it is like 10 times faster on all tasks. And I would like to note that fan on this laptop isn't even running all the time - if just browsing the internet it doesn't even spin... so I would speculate Ryzen could be cranked all the way to W25TDP and existing cooling in the laptop would still be able to cope. So... the key problem is that upgrade parts are never made. If somebody would take new MB for my 9 years old laptop, it was made in a way that it could be upgraded and because of advancement in efficiency I can increase it's power like 10x and still manage the TDP within what is ultra-slim laptop. https://www.notebookcheck.net/Review-Update-Samsung-Series-9-900X3C-A04DE-Subnotebook.83079.0.html In summary, the claim that you cannot tightly integrate laptop and make it desirable is bullshit. If Samsung managed to make this ultra-slim allow laptop without using any glue in 2012, then it is possible to do. The FLEX... there is NONE - it is precisely machined aircraft grade aluminium unibody - it is as solid as solid piece of aluminium alloy could be. One other thing - the way Samsung designed it doesn't require unplugging any flex cables before you can start upgrading (and these could fail over time), meaning that Samsung implementation is even better and potentially could withstand much more times being opened. I am even getting questions (of what it is) and compliments how stylish it looks even 9 years since it was made.

They‚Äôre killing you on CPU upgrades. I5-1135G7 is standard, and a good CPU. Their cost difference on the two faster i7-1165G7/1185G7 CPUs is around $125, but they charge $300 to upgrade to the 1165 and $700 to upgrade to the 1185.  You don‚Äôt get more cores, or more threads for that, but you do gain some max clock speed, 50% larger cache, and a bump from 80 to 96 EUs on the IGP. You also get a few additional features the processors support, none of which will matter to 90% of buyers.   On the plus side, if you want to help ensure they make a profit, be sure to bump up to one of these CPUs to pad their bottom line. Also, looks like those may ship sooner, so you can consider part of that expense as paying for priority.

Okay, some critics here. First: this laptop is FULLY proprietary. Only one small company in the world can produce spare parts for this. I bet that if they can change RAM module into "unique" proprietary shape they would do it. And because that startup small and unreliable you can't be sure that you ever will be able to get upgrade parts. Second: because of modular design all I/O ports is same size independent of their functional density. I'm personally want to have at least 4 USB ports, Ethernet and some video output at the same time. But It only have 4 module slots that take a lot of internal space. Third: all this "magnetic", @only five screws" etc in my experience leads to unacceptably low level of reliability. Magnets is bad because they will catch all magnetic crap from outside. If any of five irreplaceable screws dies this laptop will fall apart. After year or two you can expect a lot of gaps everywhere.   But in summary, this is pretty cool thing. Just a toy for enthusiasts, but still cool.  Not gonna look into it until Framework reaches at lest some level of stability.

I think it's a mistake to aggregate the upgrade paths within the company. They would be limiting their growth potential and more likely stay a very niche product. Instead, they should become a platform, where others pay for licenses and extra support to create an even larger ecosystem of upgrades and accessories. To use Linus' example,¬†Framework could only do so many anime collaborations by themselves; but it's way easier for them to license compatibility so that any company can create anime themed upgrades, opening the door for more anime collaborations and, therefore, more customers!   The beauty of the platform model is that it goes well with their overall philosophy: a platform creates more money for its suppliers than it itself captures. It's an open ecosystem!  I think a product like this will always remain somewhat niche, but opening up to other suppliers sounds to me like a better way to faster and more sustainable growth.  Either way, I wish them massive success because we do need more companies like Framework!

I don't know if other manufacturers do this but Dell does at least in its business line of laptops have BIOS options for battery usage patterns and charging options. No disconnect option, but with their branded power management software you can set the battery to hold a specific charge range when on A/C power. For instance I have mine set to about 50% so even though I use it on A/C power 99% of the time, the battery is always held around 50% charge. I can go change the setting if I know I'm going to need to use it on battery for a while and the battery is in excellent\new condition that 50% charge is more than enough for quick usage scenarios where I need to be mobile. So that is pretty handy, at least for caring for your battery.

Polite correction. "Battery Disconnect" is not a "Plugged In" mode. It's there for servicing. It internally disconnects the battery so you can safely open the laptop, replace parts, and all the other fun stuff. It switches back to normal mode as soon as you connect external power again. It's also used when they originally ship the computer to you, due to certain shipping restrictions on devices with integrated batteries.

My main complaint about the right to repair movement was that they want to force by way of law manufacturers to make their products less tightly integrated. My belief is that if people want to get a product that is easy to repair then they should buy products that let them do that. Companies can respond and create products to suit the trend or they can stay how they are and risk losing profits. Forcing them by law is not the best way to get them to change. Ultimately companies want you to buy their product and if people continue to buy their tightly integrated products then they will continue to make those products. Vote with your wallet. Using a government fist to compel them isn't conducive to innovation. I agree with the intent of the movement, where I disagree is the way to incentivize them to let us have this freedom. Great work Framework you are exactly what the movement needs more of.

If it take some skill to repair something anyway, as long as there's no "device lock" on components people do have crazy ways to modify things. (I wouldn't even be surprised if people find a way to bring 16GB of ram to an A12X processor.) And for a consumer product that you likely don't buy extended warranty for, it doesn't matter, just mod it all the way, as long as it's not for the first year. As for drawbacks, this laptop basically can't have 80WH or 100WH battery whatsoever, and port count is limited to 4 (well, 5), which means that you can't get enough to plug a mouse, connect to external HDMI monitor, charging and use LAN network while still being able to plug in a USB drive, as that's 5 things. Up the module slot to 6 or at least provide 2 free (in free real estate) USB-C port that doesn't take up any slot would be perfect. And then, the only question is, is it worth it. It'll really only be on par in cost if you don't go the DIY route (and if you are on DIY route, there likely won't be any extended warranty option available), there's practically no room to fit a high end dedicated GPU on the 15 inch model, and when think of it, comparing to a Dell laptop you really only get the swappable ports, as Dell also allow user upgrade for ram and storage, while offering factory configurations for screen side and keyboard side.

Alot of you are so confused about this fail laptop since all windows laptop can be upgraded to bigger storage and bigger ram as well, only difference was the modular usb port, hdmi etc. (the IO)  Pros: 1. easily removable module usb a, hdmi, usb c, sd card 2. Easily removable battery and screen (But all windows laptop can be remove) 3. Replaceable front screen frame.  Cons: 1. Expensive 1000$!for base model 2. Expensive Up to 2000$ for 512 ssd and higher cpu. 3. Did not even mention any rtx card at all 3 models. 4. Current gen ddr4 slot and current gen pcie 4 slot are not modular as well as cpu and gpu in short if you upgrade the motherboard it will cost alot since it is pretty much the laptop itself. 5. They dont make their own chip, so all future motherboard with new cpu,gpu, next gen ddr5 slot, next gen pcie 5.0 will probably cost almost at the same price of a traditional laptop. 6. If for example you bought a new motherboard, you are stuck with worn lcd, worn keyboard, old gen ssd card, old gen ram, worn charger and worn or full of scratch laptop frames. For the price almost the same as the new laptop with everything new. 7. Not to mention the terrible cooling system design of laptop is terrible. Look at all the upcoming gaming laptop, they are way better than this. 8. In conclusion this laptop is not future proof, having a module IO will not compensate for the lack of fully upgradeable next gen hardware such as gen 5 pcie and gen 5 ram.

Power on AC. Is good if you're using the laptop for a server, data collection, or any application where you want 24/7 run time but there is possibility of running out of power. The battery acting as built in UPS. This might not be a common first use for the laptop but will create more possibilities for the laptop living a second  life as a media server or some other use. Another exciting possibility is 3rd party replacement mother boards. In the future they could release a board that handles the basic power management and provides a few voltages, and some input/output interfaces. Then people could design third party boards for things like Raspberry Pis, Amiga, C64, Acorn, etc. Yes, those devices might only sell a couple hundred units each but it's not like Framework has to do a large investment in development and support to make this a reality.  Another use could be as a base platform for diagnostic equipment, user interfaces, etc that will need long field lives.
I'm the CIO of my company. The instant they start making 15.6‚Äù Ryzen-based machines, we're in. I'd prefer a high-end model with GPU and mechanical keys. OLED screen option. TB4. We may wind up making modules and other things for this. Los of possibilities!

Battery disconnect - That's a really good feature. Every EV has an option to charge up to 70%, 80% or 90% to prolong battery life. Every 10% drop almost doubles long-term battery life  For example 500 discharge cycles when charging to 100%, ~1000 discharge cycles when charging to 90%. This is because li-ion batteries age faster at higher voltages (higher state of charge)  https://batteryuniversity.com/article/bu-808-how-to-prolong-lithium-based-batteries

It FAILED miserably because 1)the industry WANTS A CAPTIVE CUSTOMER BASE, and 2)turns out that people buying laptops view them as disposable appliances and as such don't care about being able to upgrade them.  I took one look at the Librem 5 and knew that I had found my next phone.  Four out of five people I show it to aren't impressed and the fifth one gets sticker shock, despite phones from Apple, Samsung, etc being even more expensive.
Product suggestion for Framework : an optional base frame for the unit with double the battery capacity and enhanced cooling, with optional ruggedized wrap. This would be HUGE for field-unit deployments, as battery life and survivability is paramount. I don't believe this would be an expensive proposition, as it would involve basically zero electronics alterations beyond the mainboard firmware detecting the larger battery option. A thicker cooling solution would also give some additional peace of mind for when it has to go out to an oil rig in West Texas in August. Additionally, a slide-over UV and scratch resistant display cover would be extremely welcome and round out the options for ruggedization. Given the very high cost of options in this market, prices such as $249 for the double battery ruggedized/enhanced cooling base, and $129 for the ruggedized UV screen cover would be completely feasible and an outright bargain compared to their contemporaries.   The market for super high battery capacity ruggedized laptops is criminally underserved, and a device from a company as respectable in ethos as Framework is showing to be would be a true breath of fresh air. If they build it, they WILL sell them to capacity.   GJ guys!

Yes, the laptop we all need in these trying times. Can't wait to see if they'll expand into phones. I hate that I can't open up my phone to change the fucking battery or storage.
Almost everything on this is great. Finally getting real upgradeability and reusability in a laptop. However, the expansion adapters ruin it. All of those included ports could have come pre-installed on the motherboard. some people mentioned less e-waste but this just creates more with extra male/female USB-C ports, extra PCB, plastic casing, and packaging. The big reason most laptops don't have them is space but in this thing, you could make it slimmer and keep all those ports. There would even be enough room to include ALL of those ports plus a more useful PCI-e Expansion slot with the connectors like the GPU uses. With that you could even get a direct connection for a much more powerful external GPU rather than going through USB-C/Thunderbolt. This could even allow you to add Thunderbolt to an AMD system, providing you pay the Intel tax for it. Any further expansion beyond those ports can easily be done with dongles as that is all those are, just dongles with slots to fit them inside. Removing the wasted space from the adapters would also give more room for better cooling, as what is there doesn't look like it would cool the top CPU's without throttling. This kind of reminds me of the Moto Z2 or LG G5 which flopped for the same reason they were made for.

Love the concept, disappointed that the one thing that forces most laptop replacements is still an issue though, no replaceable discrete gpu.  I've made a long career of laptop repair and support, and my thoughts are this:   Other than the slottable usb-c dongles, the rest is already replaceable in many laptops. E.g. the USBC acts as Displayoutput. So there is so need to swap something as it can be used for HDMI or Displayport (without the need of those 2 upgrade parts). Clean on the right side (i/o is on left and back) Optical mechanical keyboard (try to upgrade this) 2TB SSD Raid (enough to me, also upgradeable without bandwidth loss like from the upgradeable laptop) so the only benefit is that u can choose i/o ports which isnt needed cuz u only gain the HDMI / Displayport choice which is obsolete by having usbc displayoutput (which can deliver both as mentioned). not mentioning the 300fps ips display that cant be upgraded on this one and more.  rly good features that are usefull: Hardwareswitch for mic and the option to disable the battery in the bios. im not against it, dont get me wrong, i just dont see the WOW effect, as the mainparts that decide if ur laptop is still good (CPU and GPU) arent modular. and any laptop can upgrade to ssd/nvme and upgrade the ram, so by choosing this one u gain modular Display i/o and u can decide on which side the usbs should be, amazing ^^  i also dont think its handy to repair, cuz what will happen, instead of having a dead usb or whatever, u just have a dead upgradeslot - which is the same right? On the other hand i guess its easier to resolder a new usb to the board instead of resoldering the upgradeable slot from this laptop here which is far more inside and by this harder to work on (easier to damage the board and surrounding chips then). only benefit is, lets say ur displayout is broken, with that laptop u still got 3 other trys by using the other 3 upgradeslots.

I love the concept and I hope upgradable laptops are a viable alternative for sealed units, but it will only see success if it appeals to the masses and the enterprise.   To that end, it should have exceptional after-sales service for folks who rather take the computer to the manufacturer than tinker with it themselves, especially when the unit is under warranty.  Also, the company making this should iterate and release new product upgrades at a set schedule and provide long term out of warranty (even if paid) support for the old hardware so that the general consumer can build trust.  Personally, this laptop is not for me, since I use Mac for its software, but for anyone not committed to Apple ecosystem, this looks like an exceptional choice.

imagine still wearing masks lol.
I'm sorry, but the 'modular I/O' is a bit dumb. It's a puck that converts a type C port to whichever I/O port you want, nothing groundbreaking, all it does is internalize a single port dongle. At that point, I would rather use a dongle, as most of my dongles are either small adapters or multi-port adapters, rather than carrying around a bunch of pucks that I would have to switch out if I wanted a different I/O configuration. It honestly doesn't make sense to have four modular ports, when you could just have four type C ports with a dongle. If you really want or need a broader port selection, then buy a product that comes with that port selection, or just use dongles like a normal person. It's a design choice that only takes up space and increases costs of the product. Honestly, each one of those modular pucks could house at least two ports, except a full size HDMI or DP port, but they could just use mini/micro variants instead, but at that point just use a type C port that has mode switching for eDP. If the spec is USB 4, hubs will become more available and dongles will become even more useful, so again what's the point of internalizing a bulky dongle, when at this point it'll just become a limiting factor for I/O expandability. The only interesting concept here is the storage, but again why not just use typical external drives instead, or if you really need that extra storage why not just upgrade the internal storage so that you also have better performance. It's the classic boardroom idea that doesn't make sense in reality. "let's do this and this," but at what cost? Just throw all type C ports on the device, people can use dongles and hubs like a typical person and not bitch about it. Honestly, if you do bitch about dongles and hubs, you need to get over yourself, and maybe pull your head out of your ass before you suffocate.

Modular laptops aren't something new. In fact I've seen super cool modular laptops from different brands like Asus, Dell, HP and Fujitsu to name a few. For example I've seen a laptop where you can choose between a discrete GPU or a battery. I've recently discovered that my old Fujitsu P771 has a freaking projector module that can be inserted in the place of the second battery/DVD bay. Although you can change basically every part of these laptops, the problem stays the same over the years. We need a standard for modular laptop parts. Currently I can't upgrade almost anything of my good old modular laptop. They don't offer higher capacity batteries, better CPU for this slot, even the projector is more like a collectable. The parts I've managed to upgrade are the RAM from 8 to 16GB and also the storage with 1TB SSD (I don't need more for now). I still use it and I love it, but the modularity is a matter of support. If we have some standard, then we can relay on third party modules. That's why USB is so important and popular way to add hardware to your computer. I guess USB killed PCMCIA and now days nobody wants anything else.

This is cool. But not allowing for repairability never had anything to do with how capable laptop companies are and everything to do with the bottom line. Designing a laptop to be easily repairable is invariably going to be more difficult, and include more parts to produce, adding to cost. Consumers didn't consider upgradability and maintenence as an important part of their shopping priorities. Laptops that aren't repairable and upgradeable need to be replaced more often. For all these reasons, laptop companies do not become more profitable by making them repairable or upgradeable. So they don't.

I mean it's cool, but we have been burned with this kind of modular tech many times before. The problems are many, like how to keep manufacturing and assembly costs down, but the main problem is that most people do not care at all about modularity or upgradeability. Being the "tech guy" in my circle, no matter how i preach about these kinds of things, unless i do the research and the work for them, they just go to a store and ask for a thing in their price range and get a thing that looks nice and meet the minimum requirements for the thing they use it for. People have enough shit to deal with, and researching these things for someone who is not into tech rarely comes into the priority list. Unless this kind of mentality changes, the modular and upgradable tech will be a niche at best and fail miserably at worst.

This might be a controversial opinion, but the expansion modules are not my favorite.   If you look at the images, and listen to Linus' description in the video, the "expansion" modules just connect to the laptop via USB-C.   So they're just dongles.  But inside the laptop. Which is worse!   Now they take up valuable space that could have been more battery, or cooling, or interior expandable storage (which could be high speed and thus usable for a bootable OS).   They should have just made all i/o USB-C and offered dongles during the configuration and checkout.   Don't get me wrong, I love the idea and fully support the vision, just not sure the expansion modules are really a good implementation of that.

Modularity - who cares?  An extremely interesting product.  On a sort of off topic, the LG G5 mobile phone tried to create a modular device and it pretty much got them nowhere. The reason being, they came up with a solution to a problem that no one was aware of.   On the note of right to repair, this design would definitely score them an A+  in terms of design and repair; however for the average consumer, the merits of its design is as important as the LG G5's design approach  in that, it's something people could care less about.  Nonetheless, if the modularity could extend to upgradable GPUs - which I know require extra thermal and power consideration than simply plugging in a smallish, square box to the side - then you'd have much more compelling argument that would in fact bring people on board.

If they sell enough to create a stable foundation, small businesses that need to squeeze every ounce of value out of their laptops and need them to be sure that repairs will be affordable and available should look to companies like this first. As a consumer my wish list for the future of framework is: - touchscreen option - another version with dgpu (maybe a 15") - Surface-style tablet PC with pen support Linus mentioned magnetic connectors.  I'd also kill for a magnetic thunderbolt compatible connector standard.  I recently decided to try out magnetic usb cables and while there is no standard for these, I just bought a bunch that I use in my own home/office/car and they've been fantastic, but they only do usb-2.0 data rates (the ones I got are Volta brand).  I still use my Surface Pro 3 and the connector is great for that.  As much as USB-C standardization is great in some ways, I wish that there were a standard for a magnetic connector as well.
Finally laptop that is not anti-repair, anti-consumer and environmentally unfriendly. Just like Linus; I'm sold.

Tldr, until we get all standard parts in laptops like we do in desktops products like these do nothing.  First off, i love the idea behind this and i realise they are one of the few who actually tried making a product like this. But, in the end you're still realiant on their proprietary modules for outside expansion. I realise that's better than nothing but its still incredibly limiting. The dream would be using all standard parts, which is very much possible but it is very hard to integrate into a pretty looking device. The replaceable mobo and their cpu roadmap sounds amazing, but in the end you again are reliant on framework supporting the product and coming through with the upgrades. As we have sodimm's for laptop ram, we need standard mobos and replacable cpu's. Until then products like this are stopgaps at best and marketing ploys for techies at worst.  At the end of the video Linus says it himself, they designed the product in a way that you have to come to them for upgrades. it's been next to impossible to find a decently priced laptop with the arrangement of I/O not to mention reliability for the last couple of years. With so many laptop manufacturers screwing over the end users countless times and in different ways. If you don't pay enormous amounts of money for what you want, you can't get it, but in doing so they then stuff a bunch of other shit in the laptops that only contribute to it's far earlier demise or add additional costs for things we don't even need.  The most common irritation is the fact that so many will segment their laptops in such a way, that getting what you need ends up with a dedicated gpu being thrown into the mix that you don't need at all.  I'm a retailer, and i get constant customers that are frankly fed up with what is available, many aren't clearly aware of what they actually need either, but if there is one thing that is a certainty, it's that adding a dedicated gpu to a system, is that it's going to be the primary likely problem in the future, be it through all out failure, or the fact that even if it's not "running"... it's still eating power unnecessarily. Much like literally anything else on the planet, the more shit you jam into a tight space as a "feature".. the more things can go wrong and will go wrong that had it not been there at all, likely would result in a far greater lifespan and functionality in the future, plus it just costs less.  If framework can provide some Ryzen 5000 series APUs without any additional dedicated gpus, keep temps low, keep good modularity, i'm sure i could sell dozens if not hundreds of these laptops to customers waiting.   OH, and one other thing, USB type A ports and most certainly C, if there is one thing that utterly kicks ass for this modularity, is that the shear number of people that have destroyed their usb ports, being forced to replace the entire laptop, simply pulling the modular part out and sliding in a new one is game changing. If it isn't dead dedicated gpus killing laptops prematurely, it's the charge ports/usb ports that have made them useless as well.

Clevo (variously rebranded as Sager, Eurocom, etc.) offers even more user upgradable laptops with upgradable CPUs and upgradable MXM GPUs (sometimes models even offer dual MXM slots for SLI configurations) and significantly higher RAM densities and drive densities (while I haven't tried to run an OpenZFS RAIDz3 on one, it seems maybe viable).  Novena Kosagi, from 2014, offered complete schematics, and 0 NDA to get more information on it.  In other words, there are better options already extant on the market for those who sincerely want more longevity and documentation than Framework, already.  Moreover, your mention of Microsoft and Apple having exclusive rights to magnetic charging systems seems questionable at best. Zojirushi water boilers have had magnetic power plugs long before Apple's MagSafe was ever a thing. Having previously helped recreate prior art to invalidate spurious patent claims for the likes of Fortune 25, precedence and prior art is acknowledged in courts of law. It may be true that Microsoft or Apple were granted patents on their specific implementations of such technologies, but there is absolutely nothing preventing others from implementing their own variants. Also see: the plethora of USB-C magnetic charging options, e.g. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fv3o2rxqYMg  Albeit, having used some of the USB-C magnetic variants, I still think Apple's MagSafe was a far superior implementation of such things.
